somethingdifferentagain?!

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my kind of dinner! Easy and a unique, yummy flavor.  I thought it might be just a bbq sauce; but it is much more... It reminds me a little of Cuban food.
Some of the reviews said this was too sweet. My guess is it was their stewed tomatoes. This was not a real sweet dish with PLAIN DICED CANNED TOMATOES(instead of stewed)like I used. The idea of adding onion (esp. RED onion)sounds, to me, like it would be great; but I don't think mushrooms would work with this(and I love mushrooms). I think, a mix of sliced red onion,and red, yellow and green peppers (in the last 15 min.) steamed in the sauce, would compliment this sauce better; although the recipe is perfect just  AS IT IS.
I made with white rice and stir-fried, garlicky, fresh-cracked peppered green beans to make a meal. Although, any starch (noodles, rice etc.) and any green vegetable would be excellent with it. 
It made about a cup of sauce with flavorful chunks of tomato that we spooned over the chicken and rice. I made only four breasts, so I will double sauce for more servings. 'Gotta' have enough of the sauce to add to the rice!
Nancy, you said your husband hasn't gotten sick of this in 15 years... mine liked it a lot too. I have a feeling I will be making for the next 15 years, also. Thank you so much for sharing this one!

text:
I would rate this even higher - these are ingredients you normally have on hand or they can easily be substituted.  I scaled it to three using the exact measurements provided when scaled down.  As a preference I used canned diced tomatoes, chicken broth (had it left over in the frig - water would have been fine), cayenne pepper since I didn't have hot pepper sauce.  Followed other reviewers suggestions and added a small onion sliced into rings - I would never leave that out now. Also had some leftover corn in the frig which I threw in at the end.  I pounded the breasts so they would be the same thickness, cooked them in 25 min. and they were incredibly moist.  Keep an eye on it when it simmers - I did have to add some more broth which was fine - it held its rich, spicy flavor and was great over the rice. Another keeper.  Thanks Nancy.

text:
VERY GOOD! Per previous reviews, I used 1/4 cup red wine and 1/4 cup water and served all over white rice. Next time, I think I will add some chopped onions and fresh mushrooms.  In addition, I think I will cut the chili powder to 1 tsp instead of 2 (it overwhelmed the chicken).  Overall, still really good and my family agrees that it should be on the "regular" list!

My family loved this recipe! 
I prepared this in my SLOWCOOKER browning the chicken first. (I did cut the chicken breasts in strips) I ran out of mustard powder so I used prepared mustard.It worked just as well. Because the reviews were so enthusiastic I decided to double the recipe to have lots of sauce. We had leftovers and tried this with both Whipped potatoes and small italian pasta. Yummy any which way you decide to eat it!

Next time I would like to add some green or red pepper and some onions.

This is a real keeper! Thanks

text:
This recipe is one of our staples.  We have been making it for the last year.  We do make a couple changes though.  We reduce the amount of chicken breast halves from six to two.  Also, we cube the chicken.  When the sauce and chicken is complete we pour the sauce and chicken over fresh steamed white rice.  Yummy.  This will yield 2-4 servings.

text:
I always add a chopped onion to this too for great flavor and texture. 11/1/06: This was EX-cellent!  I reduced the chili powder to 1/2 the amount, used 1/2 the amount of water so that I could do the other half in WHITE WINE; the wine really made the recipe as we've since used it and forgotten the wine, and could tell the difference. An extra splash of Frank's Red Hot Sauce doesn't hurt either! I love the combination of flavors and using all of the somewhat unusual-together ingredients to get there. The meat is tender, moist, and flavorful. SO good! A definite keeper. Thanks, Nancy!

A fine and easy recipe. I agree with other reviewers that red wine for water and white wine for vinegar worked well. I also added fresh sliced mushrooms and sliced red onions once the simmering starts. This is such a flexible recipe that "approximate" measurements of the ingredients works fine. I little more or less of anything just gives you a different taste the next time.

text:
This was ABSOLUTELY delicious!  I made and took it to a dinner party and it was a hit.  Reading others reviews, here is a synopsis of slight changes to the recipes that turned out great:

-1/4 cup of red wine and 1/4 cup of water instead of 1/2 cup of water
-double the entire sauce recipe to ensure plenty of this delicious sauce
-adjust hot pepper sauce and chili powder according to your own spice threshold
-I added diced onions with about 15 minutes to go
-I browned the chicken and then cut into bite-size pieces for when I threw it in the sauce mixture
-diced tomatoes instead of stewed
-served over brown rice

This recipes is very easy and super cheap if you already have all the spices!

text:
Phenomenal! I would give it 10 stars if I could!  I changed very little, mostly to use my pantry items: I used 4 chicken thighs, large can of diced tomatoes, 1/2 cup vermouth for the water, and omitted the vinegar. I only adjusted the Worcestershire to 3 Tbsp to accommodate the larger can of tomatoes. The other spices & sugar were measured as specified.

I added step 1.5: saute about 1/2 cup onions and 1/2 cup peppers in the chicken drippings, and toss in the garlic when the onions & peppers are transparent. Deglaze (wash down) the pan with the vermouth, stirring and boiling for a few minutes to incorporate any brown bits. Continue to step 2!

text:
I made this almost as directed except for a few changes.  I skipped flouring the chicken (personal preference) and browned chicken breasts in butter and put them in a shallow roasting pan.  Then I mixed the remaining ingredients in a bowl and poured that over the chicken breasts.  I baked it uncovered at 350 degrees for 50 minutes and served with white rice.  My husband and I both thought the combo was different and extremely good tasting.  Even the leftovers were fantastic!

text:
Excellent way to make juicy, tender chicken.  I didn't dredge the chicken in flour, I just seasoned with salt and fresh cracked black pepper, then browned in a little olive oil.  I took them out and sauteed half a white onion and about a teaspoon of minced garlic out of a jar with a little bit more olive oil.  I then followed the recipe exactly except for adding a few red pepper flakes and some mushrooms.  I served with a salad, steamed sweet potato, broccoli and yellow squash.  Great, healthy meal!  And I have enough for dinner tomorrow!

text:
Fabulous!  As per other reviews, I used diced tomatoes, and wine instead of water.  I also doubled the sauce amount.  Can't imagaine having enough of this relatively heathly reicped with out it. I have 5 kids, and everyone said how great this was.  I served over rice, but know it would work well with spaghetti.   Just to make it a tad healthier, I used Olive oil.  After making this, I think the next time I will  not dredge the chicken in flour.  I made this in my electric skillet which is made with teflon so I even used less oil.  This is a great recipe and where it is great the way it is, you can make your own little personnal adjustments and still get something great. Perfect with just a salad and the rice/pasta.   It's easy too.  Thanks so much Nancy.

I made this tonight for my husband and two small children.  I served it with rice and brocolli.  My kids didn't care for it but my husband and I loved it.  Here are some changes I made;  I used Italian stewed tomatoes, chicken broth instead of water, 1 teaspoon of brown sugar (too sweet otherwise), less salt in the sauce because I used celery salt instead of seed and after putting the chicken back in the pan I added enough water to cover the meat before simmering.  The sauce on the rice was amazing.  Since my kids aren't crazy about it I might even add a little more of the hot pepper sauce next time to give it more kick but really it was great this way.  My husband doesn't want me to tinker with it anymore than I have.  Thanks for the recipe Nancy.  It's a keeper for us.

text:
I give this a five star rating.  A simple recipe that can be the foundation for so many variations.  Right away, I sauteed an onion in the chicken pan.  Instead of water, I used vermooth which is always a good liquid with chicken.  I also had some summer squash that I threw in the pan.  Next time I might add some green pepper.  I see someone add soy sauce and that might be another twist.  My only criticism is that I thought is was a little too sweet for my taste (kids would love it).  I am going to try reducing the brown sugar a little to increase the tang factor.   My dish turned out more beautiful than the photo.  I would not hesitate serving to guests as it is easy, letting you prepare the rest of the dinner while the chicken bubbles.

I really liked it; it is very good.  I cut the recipe in half for two people.  I didn't have any celery seed so instead of using 1/2 teaspoon salt and a 1/4 teaspoon celery seed, I used 1/2 teaspoon celery salt.  Also because I love tomatoes, I used one full 14.5 ounce can of diced tomatoes with the liquid in lieu of the 1/2 can and 1/2 cup of water.  I wish I had more sauce though so maybe I'll add water or chicken stock next time.  My husband LOVED it and that is quite a feat considering we have opposite tastes.  That's why I'm giving it five stars.  We'll definitely make again.  Way to go!

text:
This was pretty tasty.  Spicy, but just the right level for us. Here's another way to make this that worked for me: Put all the ingredients in a bag and let it marinate for a few hours. Make a dish of rice and put the chicken on top.  Put a tablespoon of flour in the bag and shake it all up.  Then pour the marinade on top of the chicken and bake in the oven for half an hour.  It solves the juice problem while flavoring the rice.

text:
Wow, this was a great dish.  
It is so flavourful and the acid from the tomatoes help to keep the chicken very moist and tender.
The couple of substitutions I made were simply because of a few things that were missing from my pantry.
I used a can of diced tomatoes instead of stewed tomatoes, red wine vinegar instead of white, and 1/4 tsp celery salt instead of celery seed. (reduced the remaining salt)
My husband loved it.  I served it with a simple whole wheat pasta with sauteed veggies and the extra sauce from the chicken was delicious on the pasta as well.
This one is staying in my recipe stash for sure.

I've been trying to eat healthier, so I've been eating a lot of chicken breasts -- and I am not usually a fan of chicken breasts.  This recipe, however, changed my mind.  It's very flavorful, and my chicken was still very moist.  My substitutions (only because that's what I had on hand are) - Chicken broth instead of water, Diced tomates & chiles instead of stewed tomatoes, Steak sauce instead of Worcestershire sauce, Ground Corriander insated of celery seed.  Also I added chopped red onions, red bell pepper, and orange bell pepper.

text:
This is a good recipe... my husband and daughter really loved it.  I can't say I "loved" it but I did like it a lot and, if you're contemplating making it, I'd say go for it.  I made suggested changes... I added a can of stewed tomatoes for more juice, and I sub'd red wine for water.  Other than that I followed the recipe.  The overall taste is almost like a BBQ-style sauce... it's definitely not an Italian dish.  DEFINITELY needs the bread for sopping.  I give 5 stars to things that I just LOVE LOVE LOVE so i'll give this recipe 4 stars.  Wish I could give 4 and a half.  EDIT:  I just ate the leftovers and boy, were they good!  I think my only problem w/this meal is that I expected something more Italian-ish tasting, mainly because of the picture and because everyone is serving it w/pasta.  Personally (and I saw at least one other reviewer felt the same way) I think this would be better with mashed potatoes and that's what i'll be making it with next time.  Changing my 4 stars to 5.
ANOTHER EDIT:  I made this again, extra can of tomatoes only thing changed, served w/mashed potatoes and it ROCKED.  YUM.

text:
It's patently wrong to blast a recipe because it didn't meet your expectations.  I wasn't sure I wanted to try it based on the flavors I know I prefer.  I watched the video twice, looked at the recipe three times looked at the negative reviews and then went for it!   

I know what I like and what I can tolerate and I'll make those adjustments in the future.  I always try the recipe as produced first because you need a starting point before adding or taking ingredients away.  As it stands I'd make this one again with no modifications.  

This is good and hearty, even for chicken - perfect for a rainy fall afternoon.  I'm not sure it would be as good to me on a hot summer day.   It does remind me a bit of bar-b-que, but not the type I'd eat on a bun.  I pulled the chicken out and let the sauce thicken up on it's own with the lid off.  

Served it up with some mashed potatoes and green beans and everyone was happy.

Supreme it is! Thank you so much for sharing. I ONLY USED 2 CHICKEN BREAST, BUT THE FULL SCALE SAUCE PART as mentioned by another reviewer. I wanted a lot a sauce and there is only two of us). text:
WOW - this is good! Reading a few others I made a few adjustments. Some used red wine instead of water, didn’t have red – used white. What I had on hand, used a little fresh ground caraway instead of celery seed (out of celery seed). I had some ground chipotle pepper on hand – used 1 teaspoon of the chipotle and 1 teaspoon regular chili powder (instead of 2 chili). Some added red, yellow and green sweet pepper toward last 15 minutes, along with onions – I did that, ,but used frozen had on hand. Taste testing - recognized why another person put a little frozen corn in theirs -corn adds a soft balance. We served this sauce over rice, the chicken was juicy and oh so tender. The ‘Nobody's Strawberry Watermelon Shakedown’ smoothie I made – a perfect contrast to the meal. My husband ate quite heavily. I also did the salad and French bread - Nancy – thanks – what a WOW meal!

text:
I will definitely make tthis again. As an FYI, I didn't have all of the ingredients - Rotel instead of stewed so didn't use the hot sauce. I also hate celery seed, never have mustard powder, etc., so made some substitutions. All in all, pretty much the same. It cooked a little longer than needed because I decided in the last 10 min to throw together biscuits and the sauce got "jammy." What a happy mistake! I saved the leftover jam and used it today on my turkey burger sandwich - I'll use this recipe to make more jam. I've also decided it would be good with about any meat AND would probably work out really well in a crock-pot. So versatile - no way you can't add this to your cooking repetoire.

Addn'l, I made this for my parents and my Mom, who doesn't like anything outside the box ("why can't you just fry chicken like I do?") really enjoyed this.

I wish we could give 1/2 stars - I don't like giving anything 5 stars - thus, the 4 star rating and 5 star ranting!

None
text:
Although I rarely cook chicken (or any meat, for that matter), I really loved this recipe! 

We didn't think the sauce was too sweet, however I substituted diced tomatoes for the stewed (stewed generally have sugar added), and I cut down on the brown sugar (to about 1 tsp). I didn't have any hot pepper sauce or celery seed, so I just skipped those - added a bit of cayenne pepper instead (maybe 1/4 tsp or so). Instead of water I used some vegetable broth I had in the fridge - about 3/4 c. 

Flavor was quite good, there was enough sauce for eating over some brown rice. A salad and green vegetable - green beans, perhaps, would be great with this.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE: The second time I made this, I only used two chicken breasts, but sliced them into thirds so they were thin. I then dredged them in the flour mixture, dipped them in egg, and finished them off with Panko breadcrumbs.  This made the chicken quick to cook and so crispy! I left the sauce at the original amount, but next time I'm going to double it. I cooked the sauce in one pan, chicken in another, and then just added the chicken with a quick stir to coat and served. That way the breading didn't get soggy. Huge hit! ORIGINAL:  This was a huge surprise for me. It has been sitting in my recipe box for a year, and I finally decided to try it. I was expecting an Italian-type dish, but was pleasantly surprised by the spicy Cuban undertones. My one year old couldn't get enough of this. I did use diced instead of stewed tomatoes, and garlic powder, since I had run out of normal garlic and didn't want to go to the store. I served it with rice, and the sauce was to die for mixed with the rice.

text:
This was really good and different! It uses ingredients that most will have on hand, which makes it really easy to throw together on a weeknight when you had nothing planned. Although it uses common ingredients, I thought it was nice because the ingredients used are not necessarily ones that are often used together, and they blended together very well! Definitely one to serve over rice, rather than pasta- the chili powder gives it just a slight Mexican edge, rather than an Italian taste, so it lends itself to rice more than pasta I think. I think this would probably work with pork or beef too.

text:
This was pretty good - I made a few changes, left out celery seed as I didn't have any and substituted 1 tbsp prepared mustard for the mustard powder as I had run out.  Also left out the flour and butter - just combined all the sauce ingredients in a baking dish, threw the chicken breasts in with it, marinated it for 4 hours and then put the whole lot in the oven for 1/2 hour.  The chicken was incredibly tender, the sauce had quite a bite to it but not too much.  Made it for guests who commented on how tender the chicken was.  Served it over Quinoa and Black Beans from this website.  There was lots of sauce left over so I baked pork chops in the remaining sauce and they were really good too.

text:
We really enjoyed this meal. I was quite surprised that it wasn't too spicy for me either. I did have to substitute a few things probably changed the consistency of the original recipe, but we really liked the version I came up with and will be making it again. This is what I did: I didn't have stewed tomatoes, so I used tomato paste (with a little extra water than what the recipe calls for). I also used Garlic Garlic (by Tastefully Simple) instead of a minced garlic. Turned out fantastic! Thanks for sharing!

text:
I'll admit - the combination of seasonings does sound kind of strange, but this is a great dish.  My boyfriend does not eat tomatos, so I pureed the sauce, and every last bit was eaten!  Next time, I will use red wine for the water, and use 1/2 the brown sugar (this is very very sweet).  I threw in cooked rice (1 cup uncooked, cooked with 1 1/2 cups water) with 10 minutes to go, so I had a nice hearty, sauce with rice.  You need to at least double the sauce.  Cannot wait for leftovers today (never thought I'd ever hear myself say THAT)!!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish is fabulous!! I would give it 10 stars if I could. Have made it 4 times now, with 4 minimal changes. Used chicken broth instead of water, apple cider vinegar instead of white, and used crushed red pepper instead of hot pepper sauce. I omitted the 1 tsp of salt, and I also used less chicken, about half of what's called for, as it is just my husband and myself. I serve it with white rice. The sauce is delicious over the rice. A green veggie on the side and you're in heaven. The ingredients sound kind of odd at first, but the flavor is complex and melds very well. And the left overs are even better the next day! I highly recommend this dish. Rivals any fine restaurant dish I've ever had. Tip- to simplify, I measure all the dry ingredients out into one bowl and the wet into another bowl before starting the cooking, it makes the process much easier.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used 4 individually packaged thin sliced chicken breasts (16 thin slices) and I couldn’t fit them all in one skillet side by side so I used another’s suggestion of cutting them into bite size pieces. I needed about 3/4 C flour to coat them all then sautéed in a 12.5” skillet. Pieces were basically cooked by the time I was done giving all the pieces a turn on the bottom of the skillet. I  Removed chicken, added a double batch of the rest, let that cook to a simmer then added the chicken back in, covered and let reheat 5-10 min. Served over a rice-a-Roni pilaf with added broccoli. Teenage boys and hubby enjoyed. 4 stars because it was good, not unbelievably fantastic!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of the best chicken recipes I've ever made, and I've made many over the years. I followed the recipe exactly but used petite diced tomatoes instead of whole stewed, used a 50/50 blend of butter and olive oil for the browning and I replaced the 1/2 cup of water with 1 cup of chicken stock to make more sauce. It doesn't need the hot sauce but I had some leftover baby portabella mushrooms that I had to use up so I sliced them and added them the last 15 minutes of cooking. They were a great addition. I think the cook time is little long, so use a meat thermometer instead of the clock. Mine took less than 30 minutes and my fairly-thick chicken breasts temped out at 175 degrees.

text:
This is a thank-you note to Nancy who submitted this recipe.  Tried it for the 1st time tonight.  It was fabulous! I had to sub a couple of ingredients - prepared mustard for powder and diced tomatoes for stewed - but it turned out beautifully.  I only had bone-in chicken breasts so I used them, and served the whole wonderful mess over spaghetti squash.  I am SO keeping this recipe.   Note to those lovely folks out there who like to make a recipe their own:  This one is easy to add/subtract as needed.  I added a bit of onion and bell pepper, sauteed after the chicken and before the sauce.  You could add 'shrooms, zucchini, whatever, and the sauce will work wonders for whatever you throw in.  Thanks again, Nancy.

Would say 4.5 stars.  Nice to find a "different" chicken dish to add to the rotation!  I was tempted to add the onion and peppers but decided to try this recipe as-is.  It didn't dissapoint.  Also the stewed tomatoes I used had onion and celery in them so I think that helped.  I was going to make a simple boiled yukon potato with butter and parsley but didn't think it'd go with the chicken after I tried the sauce. Thanks for the recipe, it's nice to add another chicken dish to the repertoire! :)

2368620
Display Name:
Lindsey

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2511898.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW! I was soo pleasantly surprised by this dish.  All the different flavors come together so perfectly.  My BF Cleaned both his and MY plate, whereas a typical chicken breast dinner may go slightly unfinished as the chicken around here comes from Mutant huge breasted birds.  He was raving about this, it was great.  Made a few substitutions due to what I had on hand.  First off I did not have canned tomatoes, only 2 fresh Roma tomatoes.  I boiled quick to get skins off and diced them.  I almost did not make it because I found no other reviewers with this substitution but it was MORE THAN FINE!! I added diced onions since i didnt have stewed tom. I also subbed Chicken broth for water.  I used the same sauce quantity for only 2 servings of chicken (one HUGE breast butterflied) and I am glad I did. I reduced the amount of chili powder and brown sugar by about 1/2 tsp, it was perfect! Oh and there is always room for an extra clove of garlic in any dish, this one is no exception. I did not dredge in flour either, due to that slimy texture that sometimes happens, I am sure the flour addition is to aid in sauce thickening, but I found that a tsp of cornstarch/water worked just fine to thicken slightly.
Once again I really loved the flavor and it was really simple, quick and easy THIS IS A MUST TRY!! I imagine anyone who rated this badly may have not had the exact ratio of spices right, idk or their tongue needs some practice with delicious FOOD!!!!

Mr. LTH deemed this a "3", me a "4", so we'll round up and go w/the "4".  Oddly enough, Mr. LTH deemed this "bland"!  I didn't find it bland, in fact, I thought it might be a bit spicy for HIM! This was really delicious actually! I was a little surprised. I wasn't sure what it was going to taste like, but it was delicious! I took some suggestions from previous reviewers. Only did half the amount of chili powder, i didn't use the celery seed because I didn't have it, and I only did two chicken breast halves. I would say four is the max for the amount of sauce this provides. I used chicken broth instead of water, and we poured some of the sauce over Jasmine rice which was out of this world!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh, so GOOD!! I doubled the recipe, replaced some of the water with white wine, cut back on the chili and met in the middle on the tomatoes: 1 can stewed, 1 can fire-roasted diced. I had just started some brown minute rice when I remembered I had leftover "addictive mashed potatoes" (from this site) in the fridge. I don't know what got into me, but I decided to combine the cooked brown rice, a little olive oil, and the mashed potatoes, and somehow (weird as it sounds) it was the perfect sturdy yet absorbent starch for this rich, flavorful, tangy dish. My 9-year-old devoured two huge helpings, and my boyfriend went crazy over it! He took the leftovers for lunch the next day, and he works with five guys. That night, ALL FIVE significant others called me for the recipe! This is now in my regular rotation (and at least five other households'!) Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This is soooo good. I made it just as written but used EVOO to cook the chicken instead of butter. The ingredients come together to make this rich, yet surprisingly light, well balanced sauce. I did not have problems with the sauce being too sweet as others have said. If you put even amounts of sugar and vinegar, as the recipes says, you should get more of a tangy taste, not sweet. I served this with home made creamed spinach and wild rice. This goes into my dinner recipe rotation for sure!

I forsee myself making this often!

text:
This is a great recipe, served over angel hair. I made it the 1st time exactly as written using chicken breasts also have done it using 1” thick boneless pork chops and our favorite version is cutting the chicken breast into bite size medallions. When using pork chops reduce cooking time to 20-25 minutes and with medallions 15-20 minutes. Also I use diced tomatoes rather than stewed and I add to the flour mixture a teaspoon of McCormick Grill Mates Montreal Chicken. Awesome dish give it a try.

text:
We really liked how this turned out. It is definitely sweet with the brown sugar and stewed tomatoes. I left it simmering too high and it got super thick, almost burnt, but that didn't take away from the flavors.   Some slight changes (which I think may have actually helped) - I didn't use the teaspoon of salt. Does not need more than a dash. I used celery salt instead of celery seed (all I had) and I didn't have mustard powder so I used a little squirt of brown mustard. The result was sweet and tangy and the simmering made the chicken really juicy. I will make again.

Display Name:
Meg

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really really liked this recipe - though I did make some modifications, the basis of the recipe is really good and flavorful. Instead of coating the chicken breast halves in flour, I cut the chicken into strips and panfried. I then doubled the sauce recipe, adding half an onion (minced), using chicken stock instead of water, omitting the salt and doubling both the garlic and hot pepper sauce (I tasted as I went, until it was as spicy as I wanted). I then brought to a boil, added the chicken back and baked it in the oven, uncovered - in the same pot - for about 45 minutes. I served it with honey glazed carrots and baked potatoes. However, if you don't like celery seed or chili powder, this is not the recipe for you, as the flavors are strong in this recipe.

text:
well, i made 2 minor, and 1 major alteration to this recipe: for the minor changes, i used a can of diced tomatoes instead of stewed, and i replaced the white vinegar with balsamic. for the major change, i made this with swordfish instead of chicken--it was pretty good. the sauce sort of overwhelms the fish, but for those who are trying to get their families to eat more fish, this might be a good meal to start with. served it with couscous, but any grain would do also.

text:
I'm usually not one to gush but, I LOVED this recipe!! It has a very unique flavor.  After reading other reviews, I doubled the sauce, using half red wine, half water, and cut the chili powder in half.  I pounded boneless chicken thighs, and browned them in a mixture of butter and macadamia nut oil (healthier than even olive oil, I'm told, and delicious). Perfect!  Served with mashed cauliflower, this was a healthy carbers dream meal.

text:
I put off making this recipe for a long time, and I really wish I would have made it sooner! I didn't use chili powder or hot pepper sauce, I used diced tomatoes instead of stewed, white cooking wine in place of the water and 1/4 tsp. celery salt instead of the celery seeds. I served this with angel hair pasta and French bread and it turned out AWESOME. Next time I will probably double the sauce and use chicken tenderloins instead of the breasts. This was absolutely delicious, everyone in the house loved it, even my 4 year old daughter. We almost always have leftovers after dinner, but not this time! Thank you, Nancy, this dish will be a staple in my house from now on!

My family loved this! I was a afraid of trying it with all of the ingredients...I didn't think it would taste good, but most of the reviews were 5 stars so I tried it! Great served with rice or pasta.  And great the next day for lunch! Everyone I have given this recipe to loved it also!  Thanks!

text:
This was really good.  I needed something to whip up quick one night, and found this.  I had everything in the recipe, except celery seed, so I just left that out.  I also didn't drain the tomatoes, because I was going to serve this over rice and I wanted more sauce.  I used boned and skinned thighs as well as the breasts; both turned out juicy and delicious.  After the chicken was cooked, I removed it from the sauce and sliced it, then returned it to the pan.  My kids liked it, and I found it to be very easy and yummy!  Next time I make it, I will add sliced onions; I think the sweetness of some onion would go well with the slight sweetness of this recipe (the same reason onions go well with brisket).  Overall, I would recommend this for a quick weeknight dinner.

text:
Delicious!  This was the 1st recipe I tried using the instant pot to sear and pressure cook the chicken.  Only used 2 breasts and pounded them just enough to even out the thickness.  The rest of the ingredients and amounts were kept the same as written except I didn't add any salt (Dr's orders), or celery seed (all out).  Used chicken stock in place of the water.  Under pressure the flavor went deep into the breasts and they were very tender.  Will definitely make this again  Had plenty of sauce left over.  Strained the liquid and used it to make rice the next day.  Add a little bit of ground beef to the rice and this would make a flavorful Spanish rice dish.

userID:
16639785
Display Name:
Chef Becky
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
39
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one recipe I keep going back to, over and over, with great results.   The first time I made it, I followed the directions, as written, and we loved it.  Since then, I've changed the ingredients simply because of what I've had on hand.  I've found we like using garlic powder instead of the fresh garlic, and I use fire-roasted diced tomatoes with seasonings (great flavor) and omit the hot pepper sauce.       Additionally, I like to  slice the chicken breasts horizontally into two or three pieces, place in a plastic bag and pound slightly; season with salt and pepper and dust lightly with cake flour (cake flour gives a very nice light coating), before sauteeing.  This is wonderful served with angel hair pasta and fresh steamed green beans.   I'm a personal chef - clients ask for this dish repeatedly!
Review:
Rating:

text:
What a good dish, my husband loves anything piquant with a tangy flavor (me too).  I made this with just two chicken breasts halves but all the measurements the same, in other words, lots of sauce for the chicken and rice. I used a can (14.oz) fire roasted diced tomatoes, chicken broth, chopped a small yellow onion and proceed with the rest.  I did the browning on the stove but did the simmering in the oven (350).  I like using a ten inch cast iron enameled pan with lid for this wonderful  ONE pan dish!

THIS IS THE BEST RECIPE I'VE EVER MADE!  And, i've tried many.   Chicken Pierre reigns supreme!  There is something subtle but incredibly savory and delicious about this.  I did read the previous tips and substituted chicken broth instead of water.  I pounded the chicken.  I lessened the chili power in half. I added diced red onions..  I added cayenne pepper in the flour.  I doubled the diced tomatoes.  My husband asked for angel hair and it was perfect.  I also seared spinach in olive oil with garlic and red peppers to splash on top.  UNBELIEVABLY GOOD and beautiful presentation.

text:
This was EXCELLENT. I'm sure this would have been terrific exactly as written.  Howevre, like many others have mentioned, I used a good white wine in place of water and omitted the vinegar. I also doubled the sauce recipe, using fire roasted diced tomatoes in place of stewed. Like SUNKACHER2, I added a step 1.5 and sauteed 3/4 of a very thinly sliced white onion, and sliced red and green bell peppers. Deglazed the pan with the wine and then moved to Step 2. I only had boneless skinless chicken breast tenderloins on hand so this is what I used, although I did cut them into bite sized pieces before browning. I did reduce the chili power due to personal preference.  I will definitely make this again and again!!! Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I've made this recipe for a few years now and it's a favorite in my family. I adapted it once for a buffet dinner party, and instead of braising in the skillet, I put the chicken and sauce in baking dishes, covered them in foil, and let them bake about 35-40 minutes. This worked very well. When I made this last night, I placed trimmed fresh green beans on top of the chicken in the skillet and simmered them together. The green beans were perfect when the chicken was ready. I'll do this every time now!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Chicken Breasts Pierre Haiku: "Fairly tasty dish. Taste was salty bbq, little watery." Guess I'll smack myself for assuming that "Pierre" in the title made this a French dish b/c once I started putting it together, I realized that it was basically a bbq sauce that unfortunately never thickened nor reduced, so while the taste was great, it was just too much liquid (and too much of a salty liquid) that slid off the chicken. I scanned the hundreds of glowing reviews, most of which changed this or that, but I was entirely faithful to the recipe. I guess if I made it again I'd heed alot of the reviewer's suggestions, or I'd at least tool around w/ making it less salty, or I'd whisk in some cornstarch w/ water at the end to thicken up the sauce.

This was so good!
I was looking for a different way to prepare chicken breast.
I used fresh tomatoes instead of the stewed and added some onion, zucchini and haberno pepper as I had these on hand.
I also diced the chicken and added some pineapple chunks before serving to take out some of the "bite" of the dish.
Thanks for this recipe!

text:
This was possibly the best chicken I have ever made.  I loved it and so did my husband.  I made a few small modifications to the sauce, but otherwise followed the recipe exactly.  I diced fresh roma tomatos (instead of canned) and used chicken broth instead of water.  I didn't have white vinegar so I used red wine vinegar.  I also omitted the mustard powder because I don't like it.  I used a meat tenderizer to make the chicken breats thin so they did not take quite so long to cook.  This recipe was fairly time consuming, but it was SO good!

country:

text:
Thank you for sharing this fantastic recipe, it is a family favorite now!  I make it almost exactly as you, but occasionally I add a couple more garlic cloves and leave out pre-flouring the chicken before browning.  Since my husband does not enjoy chunks of tomatoes, I throw all of the sauce ingredients into a blender and pulse for a few seconds then add to the pan and bring to a boil.  We sometimes add freshly grated Parmesan to the chicken on our plates!  Add a side of rice and you have incredible comfort food!  (I've accidentally left this simmering for over an hour and the chicken melted in our mouths!)

text:
I made this last night.  I followed the recipe exactly but doubled the ingredients for the sauce/gravy.  It was perfect.  Flouring the chicken is important because after browning the chicken the flour left in the pan thickens the sauce. I did use only 1 can of diced tomatoes because my kids don't like them but did eat them in this.  I had no problems with the sauce thickening and used 1c of water and all the juice from tomatoes.  I also pounded my chicken breast flat because I always do.  My family loved it!!! Very easy!!

text:
We loved the flavor, noting that it is a bit heavy on the sweet side. I heard others say it was too salty, but I was happy with the amount of salt. 
The chicken is tender, flavorful, and the sauce is delicious. I shaved about 20 minutes off the time by slicing the chicken breasts in half width-wise (on the flat), making them more like cutlets. They cooked up quickly when I browned them, and I left them simmering for more like 15 to 20 minutes rather than 35 to 40.

Display Name:
aimeelynn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/689996.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious, though I had to modify it to suit what I had on hand.  I browned the chicken in olive oil rather than butter, then moved that to the oven to keep it warm, and sauteed half an onion and the garlic.  I doubled the sauce because I wanted to serve it over pasta, but only used one tablespoon of brown sugar.  I also used coriander and cayenne in place of chili powder, dijon instead of mustard powder, white wine instead of vinegar, chicken broth instead of water, and grape tomatoes for the stewed.  Once I returned the chicken to the pan I added some flour to thicken it and a pat of butter for flavor, and then let it simmer for about 40 minutes, turning the chicken over once.  Served over whole wheat thin spaghetti.  It was one of the best meals we have eaten in quite a while and I can't wait to make it again.  Thanks for the recipe!

This is going into our regular rotation, for sure.

text:
Great recipe.  My wife especially loved the flavors and my two young children also devoured it.

Like similar reviews, I added sliced onions, substituted 1/4 cup white wine and  1/4 cup chicken broth for the 1/2 cup water.  I also substituted 2 TBSP Balsamic vinegar instead of white vinegar.  And cut the chili powder in half.

I changed nothing else.  Very easy and unique flavors.  Served over rice.

I also thought that this would be like bbq sauce, but it had some kick to it, and to me, it was lighter.  I tried this dish with dark meat chicken and another time with shrimp since we had leftover sauce.  The shrimp version was quite delicious.  I did add corn starch the thicken the sauce up the second time, and it worked out well.  I followed other's advice and added thinly sliced red and green bell peppers and onions to very good results.   This will definitely be a repeat.  O, used diced tomatoes with jalepeno b/c that was the only canned tomato we had on hand.

text:
Even though the sauce was very yummy, I made the mistake of simmering the chicken for the amount of time the recipe called for. It came out WAY too over done, very tough and stringy. 

If I were to make this again I would only simmer the chicken for about 7-10 minutes after browning. Maybe reducing the sauce on it's own for 10 minutes before adding back the chicken.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As written, this recipe was WAAAAY too hot for our humble tastes (all 3 adults) and too vinegar-y as well.  Fortunately, I had a feeling to proceed cautiously when I made this recipe.  So I only put in 2/3 of the chile powder, skipped the hot sauce altogether and doubled the brown sugar to tone down the vinegar. That done, the tastes went together very well and this was a big hit with all of us,  served over basmati rice. Because my gang likes thicker sauce, I used my immersion blender just before serving to whirl the sauce thick and smoother.  Both my guys asked me to make this again.

text:
I made this last nite for dinner. The only changes  I made because I didn't have boneless chicken breasts, I used chicken tenders & instead of coating the chicken in flour, I used "pan searing flour" because it coats it lightly & the results are much better, & this is what restaurants use when making seafood so you don't get that thick pasty consistency. We loved the spiciness of it and it's a quick, easy, is done in one skillet & have all the ingredients in the house.  The sauce thickens to a nice consistency & I made rice with it and green beans.  It's fantastic & will definitely make it again!! Thanks so much for this recipe!

Absolutely amazing. I've made this twice for my family and both times they've LOVED it. The only change I make is instead of putting the flour mix into a bowl and dredging the chicken, I add it to a quart-sized freezer bag, add a breast, and shake (repeating for each breast). This gives a much more even coating.

text:
I've been making this recipe for at least four years and it's one of my absolute favorites.  It's super versatile.  I use white or red wine in place of the water (whatever I've got leftover from last night's dinner).  I have served with rice and egg noodles but having crusty bread on hand is key.  I usually throw in half a bag of frozen peas five minutes before serving and it is super.  I recommend for company as you can do most of the work ahead of time.  One more thing - I've browned the chicken and thrown the whole thing in the crockpot for the day and it works really well - super moist and such a nice thing waiting at home after a long day.

Yummy!!!

Thanks for a very tasty recipe! Looking forward to serving this one often!

This was very good.  The chicken was juicy and had good flavor and the sauce was real good too.  As many suggested, I reduced the chili powder by half and used chicken broth instead of water.  I also skipped coating the chicken in flour and just browned the breasts because that's the way we prefer it.  All in all it turned out really good.  Next time I'll probably add a little onion and a little cornstarch to thicken the sauce a bit.

text:
This was different and good. Normally silent hubby said, "I like the flavor." He's stingy with the stars though, giving it a 3.5 (no recipe EVER gets a 5). I thought it was very good, especially for a different way to have chicken breasts. I did substitute chicken broth for the water and omitted the salt. I also used petite diced tomatoes, as I had no stewed tomatoes on hand. I halved the butter and instead used non-stick spray to coat the pan. This worked out just fine for browning the breasts. Lastly, about halfway through cooking, I felt the sauce was too thin so I added a half a can of tomato sauce (about 7.5 oz).  I made this again last night, the same way as before except this time I added onion and red pepper. I sauteed them in the butter before browning the breasts. Very delicious.

text:
For braised chicken in barbecue sauce, this is quite tasty - but that's exactly what it is.  Braised chicken in barbecue sauce.  Still, braising the chicken makes it nice and tender, so that part was worth it.  I added onions after frying the chicken but before adding the tomatoes (which I would do again) and served it over pasta (which I wouldn't - the sauce isn't really strong enough to hold up to pasta - try rice instead).  Not sure I'll make this one again, but it has the benefit of being made from things that are usually hanging around anyway, so I might.

Yummy!  My husband and I are dieting so I did a lower fat version--no breading, just seasoned the chicken breasts and sauted in a little olive oil and butter.  I also used petite diced tomatoes, substituted chicken broth for water, used spenda instead of brown sugar and added thinly sliced red onions and pepper strips (frozen).  Served over brown rice it was delicious and a very healthy, well balanced meal!

text:
This is one of the easiest and best chicken recipes I have ever made. I had everything but the tomatoes on hand. I used a doubke can of diced tomatoes, poured out the excess liquid (after measuring to the listed amount needed) and added the additional tomatoes. I also used wheat flour and olive oil for health reasons. I didn't have Worcestershire on hand and substituted low sodium soy sauce and terikaki sauce. I served the chicken over a bed of brown rice and made the sesame green beans from this site. I already have this one in my recipe box!!!

text:
Just made this tonight and it was wonderful! However, I did make it with a LOT of differences, only because I didn't have many ingredients on hand. I used diced tomatoes with basil/oregano/garlic, because I don't like the big stewed tomatoes that much.  I didn't have brown sugar, so just used white.  Substituted chicken broth for water for some extra flavor.  I also didn't have any flour, so just used a mix of italian bread crumbs, old bay, salt and pepper to coat the chicken.  I didn't have hardley ANY of the spices (at my dad's, all my cooking stuff is at home!), so just used the vinegar--apple cider--,sugar, and hot sauce. very good mix of flavors. kinda runny though. will make again soon!

country:
None
text:
This is my husbands favorite dish.  Don't be scared by the long list of ingredients, I have found that I will measure out and put all of the dry ingredients in an airtight bowl and the wet in another early in the morning.  When it comes time to cook- just open and pour, it saves a lot of time.  I have also made this like a fried chicken breast with the sauce on the side.  My husband likes this better because the chicken stays crunchy.  Just make the sauce in a small pan and let it simmer for 20 minutes.  I have served it with jasmine rice and egg noodles- both were great.  This dish has such a unique and delicious flavor.

Followed recipe exactly. The sauce and the tomatoes tasted ok on the chicken, but really did not go completely over as well as I had hoped. I was expecting the flavor to absorb into the chicken more during the simmering process, it actually absorbed into the tomatoes. The browning of the chicken probably prevented the chicken from absorbing more flavor. Served with white rice. Could possibly try again by upping the sauce about triple and putting it in the slow cooker.

text:
I first started making this recipe a couple of years ago and my friends and family still love it!  I typically cook this in a large insulated wok.  I cut each breast into 2 or 3 large pieces and brown them in butter with the flour mixture.  In order to use this method, you must use a lot more butter, but don't worry - if anything it improves this dish.  I have been known to double the sauce or multiply it by 1.5 and serve chicken over mashed potatoes.  Delicious!  You can also add chopped jalepenos for extra kick.  This recipe is heavy, but oh so good.

text:
Good recipe with a nice kick.  I mixed the tomatoes, water, brown sugar, red vinegar(nicer flavor), salt, chili powder, mustard powder, garlic, and hot pepper sauce and let the chicken marinate in that for hours(didn't have celery seed or worcestechire sauce)then floured chicken and put olive oil in skillet and sauteed more garlic with some onions-then browned chicken on that and added all the liquid ingredients without removing the chicken.  Came out nice. I served over egg noodles.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will definitely be adding this recipe to our rotation.  Some changes I made: I pounded the breasts thin between two pieces of plastic wrap.  I used two cans of stewed tomatoes, substituted red wine vinegar, doubled the amount of Worcestershire and vinegar (red wine), and brown sugar.  I also added approx. 8 oz. sliced mushrooms to the pan after I removed the chicken and sauteed those in about 1 Tbsp. olive oil for about 4 minutes.  Then I added the chicken back to the pan, and I only needed to simmer for 20 minutes.  The chicken was moist, tender, and had an absolutely delicious, very unusual flavor.  Loved it! My three boys all ate it, too--not too spicy for them since I didn't double the amount of chili powder.

Unbelievable! I thought I'd give this recipe a try because of all the rave reviews and I'm so glad I did! My husband who is incredibly picky and hates sauces on things agreed to give it a chance and he loved it! The recipe looks complicated, but it's actually quite easy. Display Name:
Aly

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW! I *loved* this recipe.  The flavor is so interesting and just delicious.  I used about 7 chicken tenders and thought it was just enough sauce (even with my bigger can of stewed tomatoes), so to use 6 breasts, I think the would yield much too little sauce.  I followed the recipe fairly exactly, just cut out the chili powder and hot sauce (don't care for them).  I simply forgot the garlic, although I'm sure it would have made the flavor only better.  Thought the chicken turned out beautifully, very moist and flavorful.  Because I used smaller pieces of chicken, I only simmered about 30 minutes total, the last 10 mins uncovered so the sauce would thicken a little.  Served over pasta, which I thought was a fine compliment.

A little different, but really good. The only things I changed were cubing the chicken instead (cooking in margarine not butter), using celery flakes instead of seeds, dijon mustard instead of powder and petite diced tomatoes instead of stewed. We ate this over thin spaghetti, and it was a fairly easy dinner, especially with no produce to cut!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe!  One of the best chicken recipes I have ever eaten.  Preparation is extremely easy.  I freeze a second serving of this when I make it so I can cook it again.  Just mix the tomato mix and place in freezer bag, put the chicken in a freezer bag, and the flour and the butter in separate snack sized bags, then when ready to make it just pull it out and thaw and cook as directed.
I have read that some people don't like this which absolutely shocks me, I guess you either love it or hate it.  It makes a lot of sauce which is what the french bread is for, I could see serving it over pasta.  
PS. My children who do not like really spicy stuff, all loved this, of course we are from the south west and they are used to lots of mexican dishes. I think the pan browning seals in the juices so it is nice and tender.  I serve just the chicken portion to the kids without a lot of the sauce.

text:
I did the same as a previous reviewer and put off making this for a while, but wish I would have made it sooner!  This is absolutely fabulous.  If you like a combination of strong tastes and spice, you will love this recipe too.  In every bite you can taste all the different flavors that went into it from the celery seed to the mustard powder.  I think the people who are giving it poor reviews just aren't prepared for that.  I started making this about a half hour before my husband came home from work and when he walked in the door he was already raving on how great it smelled.  He continued his praise when he finally took a bite.  We also think this might be good with pork, so we're going to try that soon.  The only thing I did differently than the recipe instructed was adding more hot pepper sauce.  I use Frank's Red Hot and I love the stuff, so I think I added 1/2 teaspoon instead of 1/8.  I will definitely make this again and pass it around to others.  Thanks a bunch for this winner of a recipe, Nancy!

text:
For me, this recipe gets a 5 star rating because it worked well and tasted good exactly as written. The changes I made when I did it the second time were only to suit my family size and use what was on hand. I did try it with 2 cans of diced tomatoes instead of stewed(I prefer smaller chunks of tomatoes)as suggested by others but found that it thinned out the flavor of the sauce a bit. The chicken was tender. (I only used four pieces for this family of 2 and a 19 month old) I served it over rice and my husband loved it. I used red wine for the vinegar and only 1 1/4 tsp chili powder as that is all I had left. It was still wonderful and I did not feel that there was too much competition for flavor with all the powerful spices used. This is a definate keeper as is. I wonder if this would double well for company.

text:
My husband and I thought this was fairly good but not great.  I pounded and cut the chicken breasts into smaller pieces and added onion powder, garlic powder and finnes herbes to the flour before breading.  Good thing, it definitely neede the flavor.  The "sweet-tart-bbq" tasting sauce didn't knock our socks off.  Lots of work for an okay dish.  I may make it again just because the ingredients are readily available.  Definitely add onions.  I can't imagine the dish tasting half as good without the 1/2 sliced red onion I put in there.

This was "okay" -- not "restaurant fare" and I wouldn't serve this to company.  I have never even had anything like this in a restaurant.  Definitely a "home-cooked meal".  There are better "sweet and spicy" recipes out there.  It was fine for a weekday meal. I made it with 1/4 wine, 1/4 water in place of the 1/2 cup water as reviewers said.  The chicken was wonderfully cooked through and my kids (age 4, 2) liked it (and ate all their chicken sans sauce).  I personally didn't like that sauce.  Strangely sweet.

text:
This is really a great dish.  My recommendations: use balsamic vinegar in place of white vinegar and use only 1 tablespoon of brown sugar.  Next time, I will use red wine in place of the water (but this was still very good with the water).  I omitted celery seed because I did not have any.  Makes a very flavorful and healthy dish. I highly recommend.  Serve with white rice.  Blackeye peas make a nice side dish.

We've made this multiple times now. As written it is a fantastic use of a cut of meat no one in my house really likes - the ever boring boneless skinless chicken breast.  This recipe actually turns it into something good.  4 stars as written.  ------  We modified to our own preferences, and switching to bone in, skin on chicken really makes this a stand out recipe. The nutrients from the skin and joints really makes the sauce thick and flavorful. Finished with truffle oil salt and you have a holiday worthy meal.

text:
I have now made this twice. The only modifications were mainly due to my wife requiring a FODMAP diet so needed gluten free flour and no garlic or Worchestershire sauce and since she does not like spiciness I also left out the hot pepper sauce.  However, I did add Italian seasoning to the flour mixture before coating the chicken.  It still had a wonderful taste of seasoning despite these changes. Also, because the tomato sauce did not fully cover the chicken breasts in the pan I flipped the breasts halfway through the cooking.  The recipe called for 35 to 40 minutes of simmering  which is too long. I had very thick breasts and the first time I simmered them for 35 minutes and the temperature was 190° but the chicken was not dry or  seemingly over cooked. The second time I simmered them for just 30 minutes and their temperature was still 185° but again they still were moist and not tough even though I had not pre-brined them.  Next time I think I will go with 25 minutes or else take their temperature in 20 minutes.  If they are cooked to just 165° I am sure they will even be far more moist and less dry.  All in all, however, this is one of the best chicken breast dishes I have ever tasted and not needing to pre-brine them certainly saves a lot of time.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-03T23:27:09.573

I've made this dish several times and my family absolutely loves it! Another reviewer suggested omitting the additional water. I've made it both ways and I prefer it without the added water. Regardless, the dish always has great flavor. 

I hate cooking but I find this recipe easy to follow. I've made it using chicken breast, thighs, or drumsticks - it's versatile for whatever I have on hand or whatever is on sale.

As the chicken simmers, I make rice. A few minutes before the chicken is done, I add fresh or frozen green beans to round out the meal. Thank you!

text:
This turned out to be quite good - not exactly a barbecue sauce,  as one reviewer suggested, but still very nice for a change.  I used diced tomatoes and cooked them for about 10-12 minutes to cook the tomatoes down before adding the chicken breasts back in, because my daughter-in-law has an issue with the texture of tomatoes; otherwise I followed the recipe.  She even said she would like me to make them again!  My only caution is to check your chicken often while cooking - mine was at 160 degrees after 30minutes, so check often, or you might have the dreaded “rubber chicken “.  Thank you for a nice addition to my dinner options!

userID:

Display Name:
Donna from CA
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe! My picky Cuban husband loved it ?? So few recipes are spot on and, this one I really did not need to tweek at all. My whole family loved it. It is definitely, a keeper. Only thing I would change is, you do not need to use paper towels to drain chicken once it is done being browned. Just place chicken in a baking dish and set aside covered with foil, while you start the steps for the sauce. I did not have distilled white vinegar so, I used white wine vinegar instead and it turned out fantastic. I decided not to add the hot pepper sauce until I blended all the other ingredients and, as the sauce was boiling, it smelt kind of spicy in flavor so, I opted to not add the hot sauce after all. The dish was not spicy at all and was so delicious. I think next time I will try it with the hot pepper sauce but, to be honest with you, the hot pepper sauce could remain optional. It didn't make or break the recipe. There was plenty of sauce for all of the chicken so there was no need to double the recipe for the sauce. A lot of times recipes leave you short on the sauce. Not this one. I'm French and Italian and my husband is Cuban. So, we love our garlic. I added 3 cloves of garlic instead of 1.

text:
I'm not quite sure how I feel about this dish. It's not something that I would typically make, however, I have had it in my "saved" list on this site for 5 years so I decided that I needed to give it a try tonight! I followed the instructions and the final product was tasty but different. Most of my family enjoyed this. One reviewer said it tasted "Cuban", which may be accurate. I doubled the sauce. I didn't have celery seed so I left that out. In place of some of the chili powder I used a 1/2-tsp of Indian chili pepper (hot) which gave the dish a nice kick. I served this over basmati rice, but my Dad had it over spaghetti which he enjoyed. It might be good with some onions and mushrooms as others have suggested... it did feel like it was missing a vegetable. **Update** I ate this reheated for lunch the next day and its official, I don't like it. Wont make again.

text:
In dishes like this, it's all about the sauce. It was great. I eyeballed the ingredients, so my sauce was a bit too spicy, but I did take other reviewers' suggestions and substituted water and white vinegar for red wine and balsamic. I don't like breaded fried meat, so I just diced and sauteed the chicken (in a bit of olive oil), then added it to the sauce. Instead of serving it on a bed of greens as suggested, I mixed in some cooked elbows, and it became a great casserole! Even picky kids enjoyed it!

dateLastModified:

userID:
7643181
Display Name:
Sharon White
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
18
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3324620.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The sauce was doubled based on other's recommendations. 
 I did not add the extra brown sugar, as there is sugar in the stewed tomatoes.  For a chipotle flavor I added liquid smoke.  Also, one yellow onion, one red bell pepper and one green bell pepper were sliced and added to the sauce and were able to cook while the sauce simmered a short while.

The breasts were browned in olive oil prior to the sauce being made.   I placed them in a 9x13 glass pan, poured the 
sauce over them and baked it uncovered at 350 degrees for 50 minutes.  This was made for a small dinner party and I wanted a nice presentation and did not want the meal simmering on the stove while my guests were enjoying their appetizers.

I served it with a salad, sauteed asparagus and ciabatta bread.  There is enough sauce and chicken left over to enjoy it over rice as a second meal.  Delicious and an absolute winner.  All my guests enjoyed it.

text:
Only two chicken breasts. Same quantity of sauce (used half can of chicken broth instead of water). After searing both sides in a cast iron skillet, I put the chicken, still in the skillet, in an oven pre-heated to 350 and then turned oven off when the skillet was put in the oven.  This extra time allowed me to pick up my husband from the airport. The hot skillet continues to cook the chicken. I removed chicken from skillet and made sauce (adding Sriracha). After sauce came to a boil, I put in the chicken with the lid. And the chicken turned out tender and the sauce flavorful.

WE LOVED IT, especially since I always like &n appreciate a recipe for a tasty, quick, & E-Z dinner on a busy day!  I have a well stocked pantry, but I always use 'lower sodium' products (anything which comes out of a jar, a can, or a bottle).  IMO, by doing so, it doesn't actually affect the recipe by much, (since everyone can add salt at the table, if they wish.)  In the last step, I added a generous handful of sliced 'Baby Bella Mushrooms' while simmering.  I served this dish over a bed of buttered whole grain linguine, with fresh chopped Italian Parsley over it all.  It was SERIOUSLY DELICIOUS!

text:
With apologies to those who think you shouldn't make a review if you altered the recipe, I don't measure when I cook something like this. And I'm not about to follow a recipe if I think I can improve it. So here goes -

I pounded the breasts and seasoned but skipped the flour, cooking them in olive oil and butter. After taking them from the pan I caramelized onions, then deglazed the pan with wine. For tomatoes I used fire roasted diced. I added the other ingredients to taste and used red pepper flakes instead of chili powder.

We enjoyed this a lot and some of the family had seconds. It really was quick to make and quite tasty. I'll be making this, or some form of this, again.

At 357 calories (with half a cup Uncle Ben's basmati rice) this dish is super tasty! I prepped per instructions, but simmered on low in the crock pot for 4 hours rather than in the frying pan for 40 minutes. I added a diced orange bell pepper for good measure...this was SUPER savory and delicious. It's definitely a meal I'll make again.

region:

country:

text:
This was surprisingly good. I subbed prepared spicy brown mustard for the mustard powder, low sodium soy sauce for the worsteschire sauce and celery flakes (those dehydrated bits of celery) for the celery seed. I also used regular tomatoes instead of stewed, because I really didn't want to go to the store and I had all the basic flavors already.  Also, I didn't flour the chicken, and omitted the salt entirely.  I cut two huge chicken breasts to make them thinner, and only had a shade over a teaspoon of chili powder, but kept everything else the same.  It smelled amazing and heated up even better the next day.  Boyfriend didn't overly like it, but I'll make it again. It was enough chili powder flavor for me. I think if you used stewed tomatoes it would be too sweet but this was just right. I think next time I will add some onion and summer squash or zucchini. I might figure out this cooking thing yet lol.

userID:
3011231
Display Name:
tencms
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good and different way to prepare the ubiquitous boneless, skinless chicken breasts that have become a staple of our diet.  I doubled the sauce but not the chili powder (personal preference) and salt, and omitted the celery seed and hot sauce (because I didn't have any on hand).  This is a great alternative to boring breasts and can be tweaked to suit your personal tastes and the contents of your pantry.

Of note, I like my food fairly salty but found the half-serving more than sufficient:  it would have been too salty if not served with egg noodles.  The chicken came out pretty much fork-tender which isn't easy to achieve with breasts.  The flavor is tangy-sweet with (at a half-portion of chili powder) just a hint of warmth that most any sensitive stomach should be able to handle without pulling out the antacids.  

I would typically have all the ingredients in my pantry, so this will probably enter the rotation of go-to meals for our family.  The egg noodles were good, but could easily be replaced with pretty much whatever you prefer.  I think next time I'll plan ahead to have some fresh, crusty bread to soak up the juice and a green salad instead of noodles or rice.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-05-25T21:48:15.17
helpfulCount:

text:
My SO is picky and dislikes spicy foods but LOVES  this recipe. I enjoy it too but not  the mess of "frying" chicken. I finally got wise and began  using a Dutch oven to brown the chicken and leaving it in the pan. Also, while it's browning, I microwave the sauce ingredients (always doubling it), with 2 TB of butter. When the chicken is brown, I carefully stir  into the chicken and simmer as directed  It tastes just as good but is much less time consuming and there are always leftovers. Thighs also taste great.

Definitely 5+ stars - I used chicken thighs, chicken broth in lieu of water, espresso balsamic instead of white vinegar.  I didn't think this was spicy at all and I used far more of each of the spices.  I did not add onion although I think I will next time.  I agree with everyone that posted - this can go with rice, pasta, great enough alone, etc.  I served with roasted brussel sprouts (halved, drizzled with olive oil, sea salt and cracked pepper) I only lightly salted the flour - I did not use any other salt and it was great!

text:
My goodness! This was yummy! I made a couple of little changes... I didn't put in the celery seed because I didn't have any. I didn't put in the water because my can of tomatoes was a bigger one. I used only 2 chicken breasts cut into strips because there are only two of us. I used garlic powder instead of fresh garlic but those are insignificant changes I think. I served it with penne pasta and just dumped the drained pasta into the chicken & sauce for a couple of minutes at the end. There is a little bit of heat to the sauce but we loved it. I will certainly be making this again! Oh I forgot, one of the reviews said it was too salty so I left out the salt on the chicken and the salt in the sauce. I think that was the right decision. One could always add some when eating if it seemed to need it but I thought it was perfect without that salt.

delicious.  i actually modified the recipe due to the fact i made it last minute and didn't have all the ingredients.  It was a life-saver for a day i didn't know what to have for tea!

text:
I had thawed out some chicken breasts & came across this recipe while browsing thru the website. I had everything on hand & thought what the heck. WOW...I am so glad I tried it. The sauce is amazing. So flavorful. I couldn't get enough.  Yes, I modified it a smidge but just because I used what I had on hand. 1) I only had 4 chicken breasts so I cut them in half like tenders. 2) I only had plain diced tomatoes not stewed tomatoes. Other than that, I followed this recipe as written. It was such a wonderful change to my regular baked or bbq'd chicken recipes. This dish was super simple to throw together & would be perfect to serve at a dinner party or just a casual dinner in front of the tv, as my husband & I did! Lol

text:
Honestly I didn't want to like it. The thought of sweet brown sugar and tomatoes does not appeal to me.   Changes I made doubtfully would reduce stars from original.
I sauteed a green bell pepper and one onion to add to the sauce. I used a can of diced tomatoes. I started to freak when it was tasting sweet to me, so I threw in a few extra shots of Texas Pete and a bunch more mustard powder to try to balance it. I probably didn't have to do any of that. In the end the flavor was so Awesome. My husband loved it too. I added this to my personal cookbook so I will remember to come back to it often.

While easy to make this is not a favorite of mine.  I followed the advice of another reviewer and substituted  canned diced tomatoes for the stewed tomatoes.  I also used kosher salt, which isn't as strong tasting as the salt that's been around forever.  The finished dish wasn't salty;  it was sweet.  And sweet isn't what I'm looking for when I make dinner.  On the plus side, it was quick to make.

region:

country:
None
text:
Will definitely make again.  Want to explore how to make it in the Instant Pot. 
The only thing I changed was I made 2 big breasts for the two of us. Made the same amount of sauce but at the end spooned the chunks over the breasts, added 1/2 cup old vine zin and reduced the cooking  liquid by half. Sooooo good. We ate every morsel. The only other sub was DelMonte diced tomatoes with chilies, onions and garlic in place of stewed tomatoes because that was what I had on hand.
Id say double the sauce if making more than 3 breasts unless they are small, then double if making more than 4.
I served with chunky, seasoned, oven-roasted potatoes which were good with the sauce too.

text:
I made with a few modifications based on other reviews & what I had on hand. I browned 3 Purdue perfect portion chicken breasts then sauteed onion, mushroom, garlic & chopped fresh celery (did not have celery seed). Added all other ingredients (but due to our oreferences, I left out the hot sauce and only used 1/2 t chili powder), & cooked as directed. Served over angel hair pasta, it was quite tasty. The full sauce amount was perfect for 3 smallish breasts. If I were making 6 breasts, I would double the sauce. Very easy and quick to make.

text:
Great, easy recipe with complex flavor .  Used bone-in thighs because we like those better. I halved most of the spices because it seemed like too much; glad I did, wouldn't have liked the full amount of chile powder, mustard, etc.  I did add back in some of the brown sugar (surprising because I don't like sweet dishes, but it seemed better for the full amount). Used 1/4 C chicken broth & 1/4 C red wine in place of the water. Used white wine vinegar in place of white vinegar. Served with salad and crusty French roll.  Couscous would be good with this. Adding to the recipe favorites.

This was yummy and well received at my house which includes a picky teen! I followed the recipe with just small changes as suggested by other reviewers: used red wine instead of water, used fire roasted diced tomatoes instead of stewed and cut chili powder to one tsp.  I did not get the bbq flavor some have mentioned and didn't find it too sweet or salty either. The flavor of the fire roasted tomatoes was nicely evident. My husband and I agree it will probably be even better the next day, so I may make it ahead of time or in the crock pot next time. It's a keeper!

text:
I used 2 huge legs and 1 giant breast for us. Otherwise made exactly as recipe state except for the salt. I never use salt in any recipe except bread when yeast is involved. Served the sauce over quinoa with broccoli cauliflower casserole ( from this site) and tossed salad. No bread! My tomatoes were the no salt added diced variety. This was easy to prepare ahead of time so when it was time to cook all I had to do was pop  the chicken pieces in the ziplock bag with the flour mixture, brown it and pour all the other ingredients in the pan to boil.  While the chicken was cooking I had the time to prepare all the fresh vegetables for the salad. Thanks for sharing. We will probably eat this every so often especially if I am short on time because we eat a lot of chicken!

text:
Mmmm mmmm mmmm.  Loved this.  I enjoy dishes where you do a minimal amount of prep and then leave them to cook, and this was one of them.  I was able to brown the chicken breasts (used three large chicken breasts - not halves - with rib meat) and mixed together the sauce ingredients (I used Italian style diced tomatoes instead of stewed ones), got my kids from preschool, and then started the actual cooking once home.  

This tasted like a not-too-sweet BBQ chicken, tbh.  The sauce does not penetrate the meat, so be sure to dump a few spoonfuls on top of the meat once plated.

text:
The reviews were so good, I tried this. Of course I had to add my touch. I used arrowroot powder and coconut flour instead of flour. I added Cajun spice, s & p, garlic powder to the mix. Browned it, set it aside. I used a can of organic fire roasted diced tomatoes, white rice vinegar, worscestershire sauce, a tsp of Dijon mustard and the rest of the spices and br sugar.  I cooked it in the skillet for 30 mins and turned it off. Reheated for dinner with gluten-free pasta (brown rice and quinoa) with thin green beans in garlic butter. My brother and I loved it. The flavor is unique. I will add this to my  menu for sure. Easy and delicious.

text:
I made the recipe almost as written. The only change was to use Fire Roasted Diced Tomatoes in place of the stewed tomatoes. I did that in response to reviewers who said it was too salty as written and perhaps that was due to the stewed tomatoes. I have no idea if that is right or not. BUT, the results using the diced tomatoes were phenomenal. I used chicken tenders (9 of them) browned as directed and because they are smaller than the breasts, I simmered the sauce (covered) for half an hour before adding the browned tenders. I let them simmer (again covered) for 20 minutes turning them over after 10 minutes and the result was wonderful. Great recipe Nancy... thanks.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
1st time I made it. We do a family Sunday dinner and the family loved it.  I made a couple o f minor changes as I cooked for seven.  I had some leftover chicken broth from the green beans I made to go with this dish so I used it instead of water.  I also did brown rice and felt like 1 can of tomatoes wouldn't begin to deal with seven servings.  I used two cans of tomatoes with basil and oregano and next time I'll use three.  The tomatoes cooked on a slow siimmer for over an hour and cooked down to very little juice so when I added the chicken breasts I added another full can of chicken broth and simmered the breasts for about 40 minutes.  It was so good it surprised me.  Everyone loved it and it will definitely be on our annual Sunday dinner list plus I'll do it for company at other times.  This ones a home run.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The second night, the flavors had a chance to meld, and it was out-of-this-world! Usually, I make it as written, but I read the reviews and did incorporate a few of the suggestions.  I doubled the sauce using 1 can of diced tomatoes and 1 can of diced tomatoes with green chiles.  I used dry red wine in place of water; and balsamic vinegar in place of white vinegar.  I used only half of the chili powder, omitted the celery seed, and a little extra hot pepper sauce.  20 minutes before the end of the cooking time, I added a sliced vidalia onion; then decided to cook it a little longer because the chicken breasts were quite large.  I did have some the first night, and I thought it was good, but knew from experience it would "rock" the next night.  It's an unusual and unique combination of flavors [for me] but I was wowed by them. I served it over orzo because I love orzo!  Thank you, Nancy, for an outstanding recipe!

text:
This recipe was rather bland.  The cook time was way too long.  Chicken which has been browned really doesn't need more than 10 minutes in the sauce.  I removed the chicken from the pan, added all the sauce ingredients and simmered for about 10 minutes and all the liquid was gone.  I needed to add more liquid, bring to a simmer and then return the chicken to the pan to finish cooking and heat through.  But  it was kind of boring.  I notice in the picture that there appears to be diced onions.  Perhaps that recipe used other than plain stewed tomatoes.  Perhaps that recipe used diced tomatoes with herbs which would certainly have ramped up the flavor a bit.
